Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effects of Intravenous Anesthetics on Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with the unit of randomisation being individual participants. The sample size was calculated based on expected effect sizes from previous studies.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were undergoing surgical procedures with potential IRI. The study was conducted in a hospital setting.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved administering intravenous anesthetics, with a control group receiving standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the protective effects of intravenous anesthetics on ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) in both animal and clinical settings.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in tissue injury, measured over a 24-hour period post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in tissue injury (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild and occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group.
